# Pittsburgh Accolades Pittsburgh is proud to rank among the top places to live, work, and visit in the United States. Learn more about Pittsburgh's awards and press mentions here. Our city is consistently recognized with accolades from major travel and financial organizations as one of the most livable cities with one of the most viable economies. We have been honored as a first-rate city for livability, culture, and economy for several years. ## 2025 - The Heinz History Center was voted the #1 history museum in the nation via [**USA Today’s 10Best**](https://10best.usatoday.com/awards/travel/best-history-museum-2025/) for the second year in a row. - Picklesburgh was voted the #1 specialty food festival in the nation via [**USA Today's 10Best**](https://10best.usatoday.com/awards/travel/best-specialty-food-festival-2025/) after finishing in second place last year. - Children’s Museum of Pittsburgh was voted #2 in Best Children’s Museums via [**USA Today’s 10Best**](https://10best.usatoday.com/awards/travel/best-childrens-museum-2025/) for the second year in a row. - Barrel & Flow Fest was voted the #2 best beer festival in the nation via **[USA Today's 10Best](https://10best.usatoday.com/awards/best-beer-festival/)**. - Pittsburgh was voted the #4 best beer city in the nation via **[USA Today's 10Best](https://10best.usatoday.com/awards/best-beer-city/)**. - PNC Park was voted the #4 best MLB stadium in the nation via **[USA Today's 10Best](https://10best.usatoday.com/awards/best-mlb-stadium/)**. - The Pittsburgh Short Films Festival was voted the #4 best film festival in the nation via **[USA Today's 10Best](https://10best.usatoday.com/awards/best-film-festival/)**. - Pittsburgh was named the #5 best destination for 2025 in the world via **[VinePair](https://vinepair.com/articles/best-beer-travel-destinations-2025/)**. - Pittsburgh was named the #5 best city for sports fans to catch a game after work via **[The Action Network](https://www.actionnetwork.com/general/best-us-cities-to-catch-a-game-after-work).** - Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens was voted the #7 best botanical garden in the nation via **[USA Today's 10Best](https://10best.usatoday.com/awards/best-botanical-garden/)**. - The Pittsburgh Renaissance Festival was voted the #8 best renaissance festival in the nation via **[USA Today's 10Best](https://10best.usatoday.com/awards/best-renaissance-fair/)**. - The 'Burgh Bits & Bites Food Tour was voted the #8 best food tour in the nation via **[USA Today's 10Best](https://10best.usatoday.com/awards/burgh-bits-bites-food-tours-pittsburgh-pennsylvania/)**. - The Andy Warhol Museum was voted the #10 best art museum festival in the nation via **[USA Today's 10Best](https://10best.usatoday.com/awards/travel/best-art-museum-2025/)**. - The Great Allegheny Passage was voted the #10 best recreational trail in the nation via **[USA Today's 10Best](https://10best.usatoday.com/awards/best-recreational-trail/)**. - Pittsburgh has been named one of the best boating destinations for Memorial Day 2025 by **[Boat Booker](https://boatbooker.com/blog/memorial-day-boating/)**, the leading platform for booking boating trips. - Pittsburgh has been named the #3 best city for hockey fans by **[The Manual](https://www.themanual.com/travel/boston-named-best-hockey-city/)**. - Pittsburgh has been named the #5 best casino destination in the United States by **[The Manual](https://www.themanual.com/travel/chicago-top-us-casino-city/)**. - Pittsburgh has been named the #30 best city in America by **[Best Cities](https://www.worldsbestcities.com/)**. ## 2024 - The VisitPITTSBURGH Gashapon Machine was recognized as a semifinalist in the Travel & Tourism category of the [**Drum Experience Awards**](https://urldefense.com/v3/__https:/thedrumawards.com/live/en/page/experience-nominations*/experiential/2024__;Iw!!JhKdOwKRoV0QTA!sxHN9kcOLfI3YlluBtnPye228b3L0d5IlwftcawSQrTgIiPzsEuUj5gMfg8sXdLXZkrEwseuTdO8hfKRlj9n-7Z9x_I2Sg$ "https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://thedrumawards.com/live/en/page/experience-nominations*/experiential/2024__;Iw!!JhKdOwKRoV0QTA!sxHN9kcOLfI3YlluBtnPye228b3L0d5IlwftcawSQrTgIiPzsEuUj5gMfg8sXdLXZkrEwseuTdO8hfKRlj9n-7Z9x_I2Sg$"). _Winners will be announced in November._ - Acrisure Stadium was was ranked in the top 10 NFL stadiums by [**USA Today editors**](https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/2024/10/03/nfl-stadium-rankings-footballs-30-venues-from-best-to-worst/75461025007/ "https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/2024/10/03/nfl-stadium-rankings-footballs-30-venues-from-best-to-worst/75461025007/"). - Pittsburgh was named among the 50 Best Vacations in the U.S. to Explore America’s Adventure Capitals by [**Men’s Journal**.](https://www.mensjournal.com/travel/best-us-vacations) - Wallethub named Pittsburgh one of the top 25 [**Most Fun Cities in America**](http://wallethub.com/edu/most-fun-cities-in-the-us/23455) for 2024. - [**Actively Play**](https://www.activelyplay.com/blogs/ap/top-20-best-cities-for-outdoor-recreation) recently

BM25.question: When was Carnegie Mellon University founded?
BM25.answer: Carnegie Mellon University was founded in 1900 as the Carnegie Technical Schools by Andrew Carnegie.

contexts.text: July 1, 2013.[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-27) Suresh stepped down in June 2017[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-28) and was replaced by [Farnam Jahanian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farnam_Jahanian "Farnam Jahanian"), the university's interim-president and former provost, in March 2018.[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-29) On October 30, 2019, Carnegie Mellon publicly announced the launch of "Make Possible: The Campaign for Carnegie Mellon University", a campaign which seeks to raise $2 billion to advance the university's priorities, including campus development.[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-30) On September 8, 2022, Carnegie Mellon announced a $275.7 million partnership with the [Mastercard Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mastercard_Foundation "Mastercard Foundation") to support [Carnegie Mellon University Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University_Africa "Carnegie Mellon University Africa") in [Kigali, Rwanda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kigali "Kigali"). Carnegie Mellon's Kigali campus provides graduate-level study in engineering and artificial intelligence. On November 6, 2023, Carnegie Mellon Trustee Ray Lane and his wife Stephanie Lane invested $25 million in support of the university's Computational Biology department.[\[31\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-31) ## Campus \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Campus")\] ### Overview \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Overview")\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Carnegie_Mellon_University_as_seen_from_the_Cathedral_of_Learning.jpg/250px-Carnegie_Mellon_University_as_seen_from_the_Cathedral_of_Learning.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Carnegie_Mellon_University_as_seen_from_the_Cathedral_of_Learning.jpg) The main campus in [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh") as seen from the 36th floor of the [Cathedral of Learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cathedral_of_Learning "Cathedral of Learning") at the [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh"), August 2015 Carnegie Mellon's 157.2 acre (63 ha) main campus is five miles (8 km) from downtown [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh"), between [Schenley Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schenley_Park "Schenley Park") and the neighborhoods of [Squirrel Hill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squirrel_Hill "Squirrel Hill"), [Shadyside](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shadyside_(Pittsburgh) "Shadyside (Pittsburgh)"), and [Oakland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oakland_(Pittsburgh) "Oakland (Pittsburgh)").[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-FR2021-5) Carnegie Mellon is bordered to the west by the campus of the [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh"). Carnegie Mellon owns 81 buildings in the [Oakland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oakland_(Pittsburgh) "Oakland (Pittsburgh)") and [Squirrel Hill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squirrel_Hill "Squirrel Hill") neighborhoods of Pittsburgh. For decades, the center of student life on campus was Skibo Hall, the university's student union. Built in the 1950s, Skibo Hall's design was typical of [mid-century modern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mid-century_modern "Mid-century modern") architecture but was poorly equipped to deal with advances in computer and internet connectivity. The original Skibo Hall was razed in the summer of 1994 and replaced by a new student union that is fully Wi-Fi enabled. Known as the University Center, the building was dedicated in 1996. In 2014, Carnegie Mellon re-dedicated the University Center as the Cohon University Center in recognition of the eighth president of the university, [Jared Cohon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jared_Cohon "Jared Cohon").[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-32) A large grassy area known as "The Cut" forms the backbone of the campus, with a separate grassy area known as "The Mall" running perpendicular. The Cut was formed by filling in a ravine (hence the name) with soil from a nearby hill that was leveled to build the College of Fine Arts building. The northwestern part of the campus (home to Hamburg Hall, Newell-Simon Hall, Smith Hall, and Gates Hillman Complex) was acquired from the [United States Bureau of Mines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Bureau_of_Mines "United States Bureau of Mines") in the 1980s. Carnegie Mellon has been purchasing 100% renewable energy for its electricity since 2011.[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-33)\[ _[additional citation(s) needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Cmu_panorama.jpg/1500px-Cmu_panorama.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Cmu_panorama.jpg "A panoramic view of Carnegie Mellon University's Pittsburgh campus from the College of Fine Arts Lawn. From left to right: College of Fine Arts, Hunt Library, Baker and Porter Hall, Hamerschlag Hall, University of Pittsburgh's Cathedral of Learning (in the background), Wean Hall and Doherty Hall, Purnell Center, and the Cohon University Center.

[Jump to content](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#bodyContent) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Wiki_Loves_Monuments_Logo_notext.svg/70px-Wiki_Loves_Monuments_Logo_notext.svg.png)\\ Photograph a historic site, help Wikipedia, and win a prize. Participate in the world's largest photography competition this month!Learn more\\ [Coordinates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system "Geographic coordinate system"): ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/WMA_button2b.png/20px-WMA_button2b.png)[40°26′33″N79°56′36″W﻿ / ﻿40.44250°N 79.94333°W﻿ / 40.44250; -79.94333](https://geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Carnegie_Mellon_University&params=40_26_33_N_79_56_36_W_type:edu) From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia University in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, US "CMU" redirects here. For other uses, see [CMU (disambiguation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CMU_(disambiguation) "CMU (disambiguation)"). | [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/bb/Carnegie_Mellon_University_seal.svg/250px-Carnegie_Mellon_University_seal.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Carnegie_Mellon_University_seal.svg) | Carnegie Mellon University **Carnegie Mellon University** ( **CMU**) is a [private](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_university "Private university") [research university](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Research_university "Research university") in [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh"), Pennsylvania, United States. The institution was established in 1900 by [Andrew Carnegie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Carnegie "Andrew Carnegie") as the **Carnegie Technical Schools**. In 1912, it became the **Carnegie Institute of Technology** and began granting four-year degrees. In 1967, it became Carnegie Mellon University through its merger with the [Mellon Institute of Industrial Research](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mellon_Institute_of_Industrial_Research "Mellon Institute of Industrial Research"), founded in 1913 by [Andrew Mellon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Mellon "Andrew Mellon") and [Richard B. Mellon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_B._Mellon "Richard B. Mellon") and formerly a part of the [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh").[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-:2-11) The university consists of seven colleges, including the [College of Engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_College_of_Engineering "Carnegie Mellon College of Engineering"), the [School of Computer Science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_School_of_Computer_Science "Carnegie Mellon School of Computer Science"), the [Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dietrich_College_of_Humanities_and_Social_Sciences "Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences"), and the [Tepper School of Business](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tepper_School_of_Business "Tepper School of Business").[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-12) The university has its main campus located 5 miles (8.0 km) from [downtown Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downtown_Pittsburgh "Downtown Pittsburgh"). It also has over a dozen degree-granting locations on six continents, including campuses in [Qatar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University_in_Qatar "Carnegie Mellon University in Qatar"), [Silicon Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_Silicon_Valley "Carnegie Mellon Silicon Valley"), and [Kigali, Rwanda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kigali "Kigali") ( [Carnegie Mellon University Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University_Africa "Carnegie Mellon University Africa")) and partnerships with universities nationally and globally.[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-13) Carnegie Mellon enrolls 15,818 students across its multiple campuses from 117 countries and employs more than 1,400 faculty members.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-14) Carnegie Mellon is a member of the [Association of American Universities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_of_American_Universities "Association of American Universities") and is [classified](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Classification_of_Institutions_of_Higher_Education "Carnegie Classification of Institutions of Higher Education") among "R1: Doctoral Universities – Very high research activity".[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-Carnegie_classification-15) Carnegie Mellon competes in NCAA Division III athletics as a founding member of the [University Athletic Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_Athletic_Association "University Athletic Association"). Carnegie Mellon fields eight men's teams and nine women's teams as the Tartans.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-16) The university's faculty and alumni include 21 [Nobel Prize](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nobel_Prize "Nobel Prize") laureates and 13 [Turing Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turing_Award "Turing Award") winners and have received 142 [Emmy Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emmy_Award "Emmy Award"), 64 [Tony Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Award "Tony Award"), and 13 [Academy Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academy_Awards "Academy Awards").[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-17) ## History \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: History")\] [![Andrew Carnegie](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Andrew_Carnegie%2C_three-quarter_length_portrait%2C_seated%2C_facing_slightly_left%2C_1913.jpg/250px-Andrew_Carnegie%2C_three-quarter_length_portrait%2C_seated%2C_facing_slightly_left%2C_1913.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Andrew_Carnegie,_three-quarter_length_portrait,_seated,_facing_slightly_left,_1913.jpg) [Andrew Carnegie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Carnegie "Andrew Carnegie"), founder of the Carnegie Technical Schools. [![Andrew Mellon](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/AWMellon.jpg/250px-AWMellon.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:AWMellon.jpg) [Andrew Mellon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Mellon "Andrew Mellon"), co-founder of the Mellon Institute. The Carnegie Technical Schools were founded in 1900 in [Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh")[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-18) by the [Scottish-American](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scottish-American "Scottish-American") industrialist and philanthropist [Andrew Carnegie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Carnegie "Andrew Carnegie"), who wrote "My heart is in the work", when he donated the funds to create the institution. Carnegie's vision was to open a vocational training school for the sons and daughters of working-class Pittsburghers, many of whom worked in his mills. Carnegie was inspired for the design of his school by the [Pratt Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pratt_Institute "Pratt Institute") in [Brooklyn, New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brooklyn,_New_York

_[Guinness Book of World Records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guinness_Book_of_World_Records "Guinness Book of World Records")_.[\[157\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-160) ## Athletics \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Athletics")\] The Carnegie Mellon Tartans were a founding member of the [University Athletic Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_Athletic_Association "University Athletic Association") of [NCAA Division III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Division_III_(NCAA) "Division III (NCAA)"). Prior to World War II, Carnegie Mellon (as Carnegie Tech) played with what are now classified as [NCAA Division I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCAA_Division_I "NCAA Division I") teams. In 1936, the Carnegie Tech riflery team won the national intercollegiate championship.[\[158\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-161) The Carnegie Tech men's basketball team was a member of the [Eastern Intercollegiate Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_Intercollegiate_Conference "Eastern Intercollegiate Conference") throughout the conference's existence from 1932 to 1939[\[159\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-162) and won the conference championship in 1936, defeating [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Panthers_men%27s_basketball "Pittsburgh Panthers men's basketball") in a conference championship playoff game.[\[160\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-163) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/CMU_Tennis_Courts.jpg/250px-CMU_Tennis_Courts.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:CMU_Tennis_Courts.jpg) Carnegie Mellon [tennis courts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis_court "Tennis court") Varsity teams are fielded in basketball, track, cross country, football, golf, soccer, swimming and diving, volleyball, tennis, and softball. In addition, club teams exist in [ultimate frisbee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultimate_frisbee "Ultimate frisbee"),[\[161\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-164) [rowing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rowing_(sport) "Rowing (sport)"),[\[162\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-165) [rugby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rugby_football "Rugby football"), lacrosse, hockey,[\[163\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-166) baseball,[\[164\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-167) softball, [skiing & snowboarding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alpine_skiing "Alpine skiing"),[\[165\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-168) soccer, volleyball, water polo,[\[166\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-169) and cycling.[\[167\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-170) Carnegie Mellon Athletics runs a comprehensive and popular intramural system, maintains facilities (primarily Skibo Gymnasium, Cohon University Center, Gesling Stadium, and the future Highmark Center for Health, Wellness and Athletics), and offers courses to students in fitness and sports. Carnegie Mellon's primary athletic rivals are fellow [UAA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_Athletic_Association "University Athletic Association") schools [Case Western Reserve University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Case_Western_Reserve_Spartans "Case Western Reserve Spartans") and [Washington University in St. Louis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_University_Bears "Washington University Bears"); the Tartans had an especially intense rivalry with the [latter's football team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_University_Bears_football "Washington University Bears football") from the 2000s to 2017. ### Football \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Football")\] Main article: [Carnegie Mellon Tartans football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_Tartans_football "Carnegie Mellon Tartans football") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Football_at_Carnegie_Mellon.jpg/250px-Football_at_Carnegie_Mellon.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Football_at_Carnegie_Mellon.jpg) Football at Gesling Stadium On November 28, 1926, the 6–2 Carnegie Technical Institute football team shut out the undefeated [Notre Dame Fighting Irish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Notre_Dame_Fighting_Irish_football "Notre Dame Fighting Irish football") 19–0 at [Forbes Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes_Field "Forbes Field"). [Knute Rockne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knute_Rockne "Knute Rockne"), the coach of the Irish at the time, was so confident that the Irish would defeat "tiny Carnegie Tech" that he decided to skip the game and travel to Chicago to watch the Army-Navy football game for scouting purposes. It was only later that he found out by telegram that the Irish had suffered their first loss of the season. ESPN compared the upset to the Appalachian State victory over the University of Michigan in 2007.[\[168\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-171) The game was ranked the fourth-greatest upset in [college football](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/College_football "College football") history by [ESPN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESPN "ESPN").[\[169\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-172) Since 2025, the Tartans play in the [Centennial Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centennial_Conference "Centennial Conference") at the [NCAA Division III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCAA_Division_III "NCAA Division III") level. The head coach of the football team is [Ryan Larsen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryan_Larsen "Ryan Larsen"), who was the [Presidents' Athletic Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidents%27_Athletic_Conference "Presidents' Athletic Conference") coach of the year in 2022. Prior to losing in the Sweet 16 of the 2022 D3 playoffs, the Tartans held a 17-game win streak which was, at the time, the longest win streak across all NCAA divisions in football. ### Track and cross country \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Carnegie_Mellon_University&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Track and cross country")\] In recent years, the

Premier [Mike Rann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Rann "Mike Rann"), CMU opened a campus of the [Heinz College](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_College "Heinz College") in the historic [Torrens Building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torrens_Building "Torrens Building") in [Adelaide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adelaide "Adelaide"), Australia. President Cohon's term ended on June 30, 2013, after which he returned to the faculty at Carnegie Mellon. On July 1, 2003, Carnegie Mellon launched "Insp!re Innovation", a $1 billion comprehensive fundraising campaign. Half of the campaign goal is intended for the endowment to provide long-lasting support for faculty, students and breakthrough innovations. The campaign brought in a total of $1.19 billion, with $578.5 million going toward Carnegie Mellon's endowment. It also enabled the university to establish 31 endowed professorships, 97 endowed fellowships and 250 endowed scholarships.[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-25) On September 7, 2011, [William S. Dietrich II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_S._Dietrich_II "William S. Dietrich II"), the former chairman of Dietrich Industries, Inc., a subsidiary of [Worthington Industries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worthington_Industries "Worthington Industries"), Inc., pledged a gift of $265 million, effective on October 6, 2011, upon his death. In response to this gift, Carnegie Mellon renamed the College of Humanities and Social Sciences as the [Marianna Brown Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dietrich_College_of_Humanities_and_Social_Sciences "Dietrich College of Humanities and Social Sciences") after William Dietrich's mother.[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-26) On April 23, 2012, New York's Mayor [Michael R. Bloomberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_R._Bloomberg "Michael R. Bloomberg") and [New York University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_University "New York University")'s President [John Sexton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Sexton "John Sexton") announced an agreement between New York City, New York's MTA, and a consortium of academic institutions, and private technology companies that led to the creation in New York of a [Center for Urban Science and Progress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Center_for_Urban_Science_and_Progress "Center for Urban Science and Progress") (CUSP), an applied science research institute composed of a partnership of institutions from around the globe, led by [New York University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_University "New York University") with a consortium of universities including Carnegie Mellon, the [University of Warwick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Warwick "University of Warwick"), the [City University of New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_University_of_New_York "City University of New York"), the [Indian Institute of Technology Bombay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Technology_Bombay "Indian Institute of Technology Bombay"), and the [University of Toronto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Toronto "University of Toronto"). [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Cmu-africa-aerial-2021.jpg/250px-Cmu-africa-aerial-2021.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Cmu-africa-aerial-2021.jpg) [Carnegie Mellon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University_Africa "Carnegie Mellon University Africa")'s campus in Kigali, Rwanda. On February 5, 2013, Carnegie Mellon announced the selection of [Subra Suresh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subra_Suresh "Subra Suresh"), Director of the [National Science Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Science_Foundation "National Science Foundation") and Dean of the [Massachusetts Institute of Technology School of Engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology_School_of_Engineering "Massachusetts Institute of Technology School of Engineering"), as its ninth president effective July 1, 2013.[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-27) Suresh stepped down in June 2017[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-28) and was replaced by [Farnam Jahanian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farnam_Jahanian "Farnam Jahanian"), the university's interim-president and former provost, in March 2018.[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-29) On October 30, 2019, Carnegie Mellon publicly announced the launch of "Make Possible: The Campaign for Carnegie Mellon University", a campaign which seeks to raise $2 billion to advance the university's priorities, including campus development.[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-30) On September 8, 2022, Carnegie Mellon announced a $275.7 million partnership with the [Mastercard Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mastercard_Foundation "Mastercard Foundation") to support [Carnegie Mellon University Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University_Africa "Carnegie Mellon University Africa") in [Kigali, Rwanda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kigali "Kigali"). Carnegie Mellon's Kigali campus provides graduate-level study in engineering and artificial intelligence. On November 6, 2023, Carnegie Mellon Trustee Ray Lane and his wife Stephanie Lane invested $25 million in support of the university's Computational Biology

continued performing the characters in live comedy routines before joining the cast of the TV series _[Laverne & Shirley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laverne_%26_Shirley "Laverne & Shirley")_. In 2008, Carnegie Mellon professor [Randy Pausch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randy_Pausch "Randy Pausch")'s " [Last Lecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Really_Achieving_Your_Childhood_Dreams "Really Achieving Your Childhood Dreams")" became a pop culture phenomenon. Based on a lecture he gave in September 2007 – shortly after he learned his cancer had metastasized – his book quickly rose to the top of bestseller lists around the country. Named in _[Time](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_(magazine) "Time (magazine)")_ magazine's [_Time_ 100](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_100 "Time 100") list of influential people, he died in July 2008 from pancreatic cancer.[\[190\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University#cite_note-193) In 2003, Carnegie Mellon established the [Robot Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_Hall_of_Fame "Robot Hall of Fame") in partnership with the [Carnegie Science Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Science_Center "Carnegie Science Center"). BM25.question: What are the three major professional sports teams in Pittsburgh?
BM25.answer: The three major professional sports teams in Pittsburgh are the Pittsburgh Pirates (baseball), the Pittsburgh Steelers (football), and the Pittsburgh Penguins (hockey).

contexts.text: in the postseason with a victory in the 2013 National League Wild Card Game. The Pirates additionally posted a losing record in 20 consecutive seasons from [1993](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1993_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "1993 Pittsburgh Pirates season") to [2012](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "2012 Pittsburgh Pirates season"), a record streak in both MLB and the four major North American professional sports leagues.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-5) The Pirates currently have the fifth-longest World Series championship drought, the longest pennant drought in the National League,[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-6) and the longest [League Championship Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_Championship_Series "League Championship Series") appearance and division championship drought in all of baseball. From 1882 to 2025, the Pirates have an overall record of 10,910–10,910–140 (.500 winning 'percentage').[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-7) The Pirates are also often referred to as the "Bucs" or the "Buccos" (derived from [buccaneer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buccaneer "Buccaneer"), a synonym for [pirate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piracy "Piracy")). Since 2001 the team has played its home games at [PNC Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PNC_Park "PNC Park"), a 39,000-seat stadium along the [Allegheny River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegheny_River "Allegheny River") in Pittsburgh's [North Side](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Side_(Pittsburgh) "North Side (Pittsburgh)"). The Pirates previously played at [Forbes Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes_Field "Forbes Field") from 1909 to 1970 and at [Three Rivers Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Rivers_Stadium "Three Rivers Stadium") from 1970 to 2000. Since 1948 the Pirates' colors have been black, gold and white, derived from the [flag of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_Pittsburgh "Flag of Pittsburgh") and matching the other major professional sports teams in Pittsburgh, the [Steelers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers") and the [Penguins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins "Pittsburgh Penguins"). ## History \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: History")\] Main article: [History of the Pittsburgh Pirates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Pittsburgh_Pirates "History of the Pittsburgh Pirates") Professional baseball in the Pittsburgh area began in 1876 with the organization of the [Allegheny Base Ball Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Allegheny_(International_Association) "Pittsburgh Allegheny (International Association)"), an independent (non-league) club based in a then-separate city called [Allegheny City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegheny,_Pennsylvania "Allegheny, Pennsylvania"), across the [Allegheny River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegheny_River "Allegheny River") from Pittsburgh. The team joined the minor league [International Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Association_for_Professional_Base_Ball_Players "International Association for Professional Base Ball Players") in 1877, only to fold the following season.[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-8) On October 15, 1881, [Denny McKnight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denny_McKnight "Denny McKnight") held a meeting at Pittsburgh's St. Clair Hotel to organize a new Allegheny club,[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-9) which began play in 1882 as a founding member of the [American Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Association_(19th_century) "American Association (19th century)"). Chartered as the Allegheny Base Ball Club of Pittsburgh,[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-10) the team was listed as "Allegheny" in the standings, and was sometimes called the "Alleghenys" (occasionally the "Alleghenies" or “Allies”) in that era's custom of referring to a team by its pluralized city or club name. After five mostly mediocre seasons, Pittsburgh became the first [A.A. team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_North_American_professional_sports_teams "Major North American professional sports teams") to switch to the older [National League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_League_(baseball) "National League (baseball)") in 1887.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-11) During the winter prior to the 1890 season, almost all of the Alleghenys' best players bolted to the [Players' League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Players%27_League "Players' League")'s [Pittsburgh Burghers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Burghers "Pittsburgh Burghers"). The Players' League collapsed after the season, and the players were allowed to go back to their old clubs. However, the Alleghenys also signed highly regarded second baseman [Lou Bierbauer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lou_Bierbauer "Lou Bierbauer"), who had previously played with the A.A.'s [Philadelphia Athletics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Athletics_(American_Association) "Philadelphia Athletics (American Association)"). Although the Athletics failed to include Bierbauer on their reserve list, they loudly protested the Alleghenys' move. In an official complaint, an AA

For other uses, see [Pittsburgh Pirates (disambiguation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates_(disambiguation) "Pittsburgh Pirates (disambiguation)"). "Pittsburgh Allegheny" redirects here. For the minor league team, see [Pittsburgh Allegheny (International Association)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Allegheny_(International_Association) "Pittsburgh Allegheny (International Association)"). | Pittsburgh Pirates | The **Pittsburgh Pirates** are an American professional [baseball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baseball "Baseball") team based in [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh"). The Pirates compete in [Major League Baseball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_League_Baseball "Major League Baseball") (MLB) as a member club of the [National League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_League_(baseball) "National League (baseball)") (NL) [Central Division](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_League_Central "National League Central"). Founded as part of the [American Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Association_(19th_century) "American Association (19th century)") in 1881 under the name the Allegheny Base Ball Club of Pittsburgh, the club joined the National League in 1887 and was a member of the [National League East](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_League_East "National League East") from 1969 through 1993. The Pirates have won five [World Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Series "World Series") championships, nine [National League pennants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_National_League_pennant_winners "List of National League pennant winners"), nine National League East division titles and made three appearances in the [Wild Card Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_League_Baseball_Wild_Card_Game "Major League Baseball Wild Card Game"). The Pirates were among the best teams in baseball at the start of the 20th century, playing in the [inaugural World Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1903_World_Series "1903 World Series") in 1903 and winning their first title in [1909](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1909_World_Series "1909 World Series") behind [Honus Wagner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honus_Wagner "Honus Wagner"). The Pirates took part in arguably the most famous World Series ending, winning the [1960 World Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1960_World_Series "1960 World Series") against the [New York Yankees](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Yankees "New York Yankees") on a [walk-off home run](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walk-off_home_run "Walk-off home run") by [Bill Mazeroski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Mazeroski "Bill Mazeroski"), the only time that Game 7 of the World Series has ever ended with a home run. They won again in [1971](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1971_World_Series "1971 World Series") behind [Roberto Clemente](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Clemente "Roberto Clemente"), the first Latin-American enshrined in the [National Baseball Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Baseball_Hall_of_Fame "National Baseball Hall of Fame"), and in [1979](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1979_World_Series "1979 World Series") under the leadership of [Willie Stargell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willie_Stargell "Willie Stargell"). Since their last World Series in 1979, the Pirates have largely endured a period of great struggle. Since then, they have only had eleven winning seasons, six postseason appearances, three division titles, and have advanced just once in the postseason with a victory in the 2013 National League Wild Card Game. The Pirates additionally posted a losing record in 20 consecutive seasons from [1993](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1993_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "1993 Pittsburgh Pirates season") to [2012](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2012_Pittsburgh_Pirates_season "2012 Pittsburgh Pirates season"), a record streak in both MLB and the four major North American professional sports leagues.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-5) The Pirates currently have the fifth-longest World Series championship drought, the longest pennant drought in the National League,[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-6) and the longest [League Championship Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_Championship_Series "League Championship Series") appearance and division championship drought in all of baseball. From 1882 to 2025, the Pirates have an overall record of 10,910–10,910–140 (.500 winning 'percentage').[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-7) The Pirates are also often referred to as the "Bucs" or the "Buccos" (derived from [buccaneer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buccaneer "Buccaneer"), a synonym for [pirate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piracy "Piracy")). Since 2001 the

The first World Series night game was played in [Three Rivers Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Rivers_Stadium "Three Rivers Stadium") on October 13, 1971— [eleven years to the day since Mazeroski's walk-off homer brought the Pirates their last World Series title in 1960](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_sports_lore#Mazeroski's_Home_Run "Pittsburgh sports lore"). In this case, however, it was Game 4 between the Pirates and the Baltimore Orioles, rather than a decisive Game 7. Apparently, good things happen for the Pirates on this date, as they knotted the [1971 World Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1971_World_Series "1971 World Series") at two games apiece on their way to their fourth title. - The first MLB scout to win the "Scout of the Year Award", [Howie Haak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howie_Haak "Howie Haak"), in 1984, three additional scouts from the organization have subsequently won the award. - The first combined [extra inning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extra_innings "Extra innings") [no-hitter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/No-hitter "No-hitter") in MLB history took place at Three Rivers Stadium on July 12, 1997. [Francisco Córdova](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francisco_C%C3%B3rdova_(baseball,_born_1972) "Francisco Córdova (baseball, born 1972)") (9 innings) and [Ricardo Rincón](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ricardo_Rinc%C3%B3n "Ricardo Rincón") (1 inning) combined to no-hit the [Houston Astros](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1997_Houston_Astros_season "1997 Houston Astros season"), 3–0 in 10 innings. [Pinch-hitter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinch-hitter "Pinch-hitter") [Mark Smith's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Smith_(outfielder) "Mark Smith (outfielder)") three-run [walk-off home run](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walk-off_home_run "Walk-off home run") in the bottom of the 10th inning sealed the victory and the no-hitter for the Pirates. It remains the only such no-hitter to date.[\[93\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-95) - In November 2008, the Pirates became the first MLB team to sign Indian players when they acquired the non-draft free agents of [Rinku Singh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rinku_Singh_(wrestler) "Rinku Singh (wrestler)") and [Dinesh Patel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dinesh_Patel "Dinesh Patel").[\[94\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-pittsburgh.pirates.mlb.com-96)[\[95\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-97) This was also seen by Pirates [general manager](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_manager_(baseball) "General manager (baseball)") [Neal Huntington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neal_Huntington "Neal Huntington"), as "not only add\[ing\] two prospects to our system but also hope to open a pathway to an untapped market."[\[96\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-98) - The Pirates are the first team in professional sports to have 20 consecutive losing seasons. This streak lasted from 1993 to 2012. This is the longest such streak in North American professional sports history. - The Pirates are the first MLB team (as well as only second in major professional sports) to be owned by an [openly gay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gay "Gay") owner, although [Kevin McClatchy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kevin_McClatchy "Kevin McClatchy") had already divested his shares in the Pirates when he openly announced his homosexuality in September 2012.[\[97\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-Coming_Out_in_the_World_of_Sports-99)[\[98\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-100) - On April 6, 2015, the Pirates' loss to the [Cincinnati Reds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Reds "Cincinnati Reds") earned the team its 10,000 franchise loss and making the Pirates the first MLB team to reach their 10,000th loss on an Opening Day.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-Wilmoth,_Charlie_2015-18) - On May 9, 2015, the Pirates became the first MLB team to turn a 4–5–4 triple play. The triple play occurred during a 7–5 win over the [St. Louis Cardinals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Louis_Cardinals "St. Louis Cardinals"). The play occurred when the Cardinals' [Yadier Molina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yadier_Molina "Yadier Molina") lined out to Pittsburgh second baseman [Neil Walker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neil_Walker_(baseball) "Neil Walker (baseball)"). Walker then threw to third baseman [Jung Ho Kang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jung_Ho_Kang "Jung Ho Kang") to double off the Cardinals' [Jhonny Peralta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jhonny_Peralta "Jhonny Peralta") for the second out. Kang then threw the ball back to Walker, who was standing on second base for the final out after St. Louis's [Jason Heyward](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jason_Heyward "Jason Heyward") froze between second and

BM25.question: What is Spring Carnival at CMU?
BM25.answer: Spring Carnival is the oldest CMU tradition, featuring student-built booths, racing robots, live entertainment, and a variety of food options. It is a three-day event that brings the entire CMU community together to celebrate and engage in the university's Tartan spirit.

contexts.text: # Traditions ## Connected to the Past, Shaping the Future At Carnegie Mellon University (CMU), traditions are more than just events — they're a celebration of our bold and collaborative community. Some commemorate the Scottish heritage of our founder, Andrew Carnegie, while others originate from previous CMU students. These hallmark experiences help create the fabric of the university, building a tight-knit campus with a creative, quirky spirit. From the distinctive sounds of the [Carnegie Mellon Pipes and Drums](https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/dean/pipes/) to the joyful energy of [Spring Carnival](https://www.springcarnival.org/), our traditions embody our fearless, visionary spirit, honor our rich history and pave the way for an extraordinary future. Explore the many annual traditions and programs where the entire CMU community comes together to connect, engage and unleash their **Tartan pride**. ## The Fence at CMU Have a message for campus? Paint it on the Fence, a tradition that made the original structure the most painted object in the world. Help our current Fence retake that title. [Learn About the Fence](https://www.cmu.edu/stugov/fence/index.html) ## Spring Carnival The oldest CMU tradition, this three-day event features student-built booths, racing robots, live entertainment and an array of delectable food options. [Learn About Spring Carnival](https://www.cmu.edu/engage/alumni/events/campus/spring-carnival/index.html) ## CMU Traditions and Activities Explore our annual events that foster the Tartan spirit. [![A racer gets ready for Buggy at CMU, 2025](https://www.cmu.edu/sites/default/files/styles/large_testimonial_grid_384x256/public/2025-05/UA_230415A_Buggy_Finals_Booth183.jpeg.webp?itok=ez5hurtC)**Sweepstakes**](https://www.cmu.edu/buggy/) A thrilling highlight of Spring Carnival is Sweepstakes, in which CMU students build and race aerodynamic "buggies" at speeds up to 35 mph. [![Farnam Jahanian at Scotty Saturday. ](https://www.cmu.edu/sites/default/files/styles/large_testimonial_grid_384x256/public/2025-05/221015-Scotty-Saturday-035-SM.jpeg.webp?itok=fO8d-nl1)**Scotty Saturday**](https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/slice/traditions/scotty-saturday.html) This daylong celebration of Carnegie Mellon spirit features CMU-themed activities, student talent showcases, free snacks and giveaways. [![Greek Sing at CMU](https://www.cmu.edu/sites/default/files/styles/large_testimonial_grid_384x256/public/2025-05/240323A_Greek_Sing021.jpeg.webp?itok=hT2_Wv-B)**Greek Sing**](https://greeksing.com/) In this annual event supporting local charities, CMU fraternities and sororities perform 15-minute versions of your favorite musicals. [![the FAIR at CMU](https://www.cmu.edu/sites/default/files/styles/large_testimonial_grid_384x256/public/2025-05/thefair900x600.jpg.webp?itok=cAGrHPgK)**The FAIR and Winter FAIR**](https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/sit/traditions/fair.html) Explore CMU's diverse student organizations and outdoor recreation partners. The fairs take place early in the fall and spring semesters. [![The Kiltie Band](https://www.cmu.edu/sites/default/files/styles/large_testimonial_grid_384x256/public/2025-05/MC_191116B_Kiltie%20Band_0030.jpg.webp?itok=HpAvsbry)**Kiltie Band**](https://athletics.cmu.edu/athletics/kiltieband/index) The Kiltie Band rocks kilts — what else? — while bringing their infectious, irreverent energy to CMU sporting events. * * * ## Our Connection to the City Carnegie Mellon’s traditions include embracing Pittsburgh’s rich culture. Immerse yourself in the city’s unique offerings through these opportunities: ### [Arts Pass](https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/slice/traditions/arts-pass.html) Unlock free access to renowned museums and attractions with your CMU ID, from the Andy Warhol Museum to the National Aviary. ### [Pittsburgh Connections](https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/slice/traditions/pittsburgh.html) Join outdoor adventures, cultural exploration and environmental stewardship across Pittsburgh through subsidized experiences. * * * ## Explore More CMU Traditions From treats during finals week to hearing the sound of bagpipes on campus, discover more CMU traditions that become lifelong memories. ### Bagpipers It doesn't get more Scottish than bagpipes. Carnegie Mellon's Pipes and Drums can be found practicing around campus and performing at formal university events. ### Autographs Behind the stage of Kresge Theatre senior "dramats" (drama students) sign the walls and ceiling before graduating. Among these young hopefuls: Ted Danson, Blair Underwood and Holly Hunter. ### Almost Midnight Breakfast CMU staff and faculty cook omelets and serve you breakfast during finals week in the fall and spring

Enjoy hands-on fun with activities presented by **Chick-fil-A** and the **Pittsburgh Pirates**. Kids can get crafty by making their very own pickle button, and try their luck at **pickle-themed carnival games**. It’s a perfect spot for pint-sized pickle lovers to play and create!

**When is it?**

Friday & Saturday: 12 – 10 p.m.

Sunday: 12 – 6 p.m.

**Where is it?**

Allegheny Landing

**What Activities will be available?**

There will be a free button-making craft table and carnival games including: pickle jar toss, pickle duck pond, pickle bean bag toss, pickle derby race

**How much does it cost?**

Activities under the KidsPlay tent are **free**.

The pickle themed carnival games are $2 per play. Carnival game tickets can be purchased onsite- no reservation necessary.

**Li’l Gherkins Activity Area Guidelines:**

- Li’l gherkins must be accompanied by an adult, and adults must be accompanied by a li’l gherkin
- One craft per child, ages 14 and under
- No food or beverages at the craft table
- Please park your stroller outside of the tent

### Presented by

[![](https://www.picklesburgh.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Chik-fil-a-logo-1.png)](https://www.picklesburgh.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Chik-fil-a-logo-1.png)

[![](https://www.picklesburgh.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Pirates-1024x512.png)](https://www.picklesburgh.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/Pirates.png)

day's event. #### What if I cannot find tickets I purchased or tickets that were forwarded to me? First confirm that the tickets were purchased with an email address that is verified on the My MLB Account Emails page which is accessible by tapping the Profile icon in the top left hand corner of the Home Tab and then tapping My MLB Account Emails. Next, confirm that a Pirates ticket account is displaying on the My Ticket Accounts page. If there is not a Pirates ticket account listed, and you’re certain that the email address you have verified in MLB Account is correct then please contact Pirates Fans Services at [ticketservices@pirates.com](mailto:ticketservices@pirates.com) or 1-800-BUY-BUCS. Note that you may need to refresh your Tickets tab by pulling down on the screen to see updated ticket inventory. If your Pirates tickets were originally forwarded to you by another Ballpark app user, the original sender may have canceled the forward and you should check with the person who sent you the tickets. If you are still having difficulty locating mobile tickets you believe should be appearing in your Tickets tab, contact Pirates Fans Services at [ticketservices@pirates.com](mailto:ticketservices@pirates.com) or 1-800-BUY-BUCS. #### Which types of tickets will be displayed in the MLB Ballpark app? The MLB Ballpark app displays regular season, Postseason, Spring Training and other event tickets within the Tickets tab’s Wallet. Tickets that you have forwarded to friends will not show a barcode. There will be a message that the ticket has been forwarded with a cancel button in place of the barcode. #### Will large group tickets with 15 or more tickets and suite rental tickets be listed in the Wallet in the MLB Ballpark app? Yes. See Pirates.com/Groups or Pirates.com/suites for additional group or suite ticket information. #### When will the tickets I purchase be listed in the Wallet of the MLB Ballpark app? Once Pirates tickets are purchased via an exclusive presale or the general on-sale, your tickets will automatically appear in the Wallet within the Tickets tab of the MLB Ballpark app. #### Can I still print my Pirates tickets at home? No, to improve security and reduce the risk of ticket fraud, print-at-home tickets in any form are no longer accepted for entry at PNC Park. [arrow-up-5\\ Back to Top](https://www.mlb.com/pirates/tickets/mobile/faqs#top) ### MLB BALLPARK APP - MOBILE TICKET BARCODE #### What is a Mobile Ticket Barcode? Each ticket has a mobile ticket barcode that must be scanned for entry into PNC Park via your mobile device. Within the Wallet, you can tap on an individual ticket to view its barcode. For entry to PNC Park, present your mobile device with the mobile barcode open and available to scan. #### How do I access the ticket to scan for entry? Tap on an individual ticket from the Tickets tab’s Wallet to pull up the mobile ticket barcode. The Section/Row/Seat and barcode will be displayed along with access to the terms and conditions governing your ticket. #### Why is my ticket barcode not showing in the MLB Ballpark app? By the 1990s, the Pirates were threatening to leave Pittsburgh unless a new, baseball-only stadium was constructed. The Pirates played their final game at Three Rivers on October 1, 2000, and the stadium was demolished the following winter. The site is currently occupied by parking lots and [Stage AE](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stage_AE "Stage AE"), although one of the stadium's entrance markers remains standing near [Acrisure Stadium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acrisure_Stadium "Acrisure Stadium"). In 2012, members of the [Society for American Baseball Research](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_for_American_Baseball_Research "Society for American Baseball Research") marked and painted the [home plate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baseball_field#Home_base "Baseball field") and first base of the former stadium on the 40th Anniversary of Roberto Clemente's 3,000th hit.[\[38\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-38) Since then, markers have been placed at the locations of home plate, second base, and the pitcher’s plate. [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/BuccoSpringTraining.JPG/250px-BuccoSpringTraining.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:BuccoSpringTraining.JPG) [LECOM Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LECOM_Park "LECOM Park"), which hosts the Pirates' Spring Training games ### Spring Training \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Spring Training")\] Since 1969, the Pirates have held [Spring Training](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spring_Training "Spring Training") at [LECOM Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LECOM_Park "LECOM Park") in [Bradenton, Florida](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bradenton,_Florida "Bradenton, Florida"), which is also used for the Pirates' minor league team, the [Bradenton Marauders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bradenton_Marauders "Bradenton Marauders"). Constructed in 1923, LECOM Park is the oldest stadium still in use for Spring Training and the second-oldest minor league park, behind only [Jackie Robinson Ballpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackie_Robinson_Ballpark "Jackie Robinson Ballpark") in [Daytona Beach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daytona_Beach "Daytona Beach"), which dates to 1914.[\[39\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-39) It is also the third oldest stadium currently used by a major league team after [Fenway Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fenway_Park "Fenway Park"), built in 1912, and [Wrigley Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wrigley_Field "Wrigley Field"), built in 1914.[\[40\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-40) Built in a Florida Spanish Mission style, LECOM Park underwent two major renovations in 1993 and 2008, the latter of which added lights.[\[41\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-41) The park was formerly named "McKechnie Field," for Bradenton resident and Baseball Hall of Fame great [Bill McKechnie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_McKechnie "Bill McKechnie"), who led the Pirates in [1925](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1925_World_Series "1925 World Series"); since 2017 it has been named for the [Lake Erie College of Osteopathic Medicine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lake_Erie_College_of_Osteopathic_Medicine "Lake Erie College of Osteopathic Medicine"), which has its main campus in [Erie, Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erie,_Pennsylvania "Erie, Pennsylvania"), and also a campus in Bradenton.[\[42\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-lecom-42) [Pirate City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pirate_City "Pirate City"), the site of the Pirates' Spring Training complex, is located a few miles east of LECOM Park. ## Logos and uniforms \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh_Pirates&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Logos and uniforms")\] - [![1888: "Alleghenys" Logo](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/0d/PittsburghAlleghenys1888.png/120px-PittsburghAlleghenys1888.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:PittsburghAlleghenys1888.png "1888: \"Alleghenys\" Logo") **1888: "Alleghenys" Logo** - [![1908–1909](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Pirates_1908.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pirates_1908.png "1908–1909") **1908–1909** - [![1915–1919](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7a/Pirates15.gif)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pirates15.gif "1915–1919") **1915–1919** - [![1921, 1932](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/be/Pirates_21.gif)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pirates_21.gif "1921, 1932") **1921, 1932** - [![1922](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Pirates_22.png/120px-Pirates_22.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pirates_22.png "1922") **1922** - [![1923–1931](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7f/Pirates_23.gif)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pirates_23.gif "1923–1931") **1923–1931** - [![1933–1935](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/eb/Pirates_33.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pirates_33.png "1933–1935") **1933–1935** - [![1948–present](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Pittsburgh_Pirates_logo_2014.svg/120px-Pittsburgh_Pirates_logo_2014.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pittsburgh_Pirates_logo_2014.svg "1948–present") **1948–present** [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Jim_Russell-_Pittsburgh_Pirate.jpg/250px-Jim_Russell-_Pittsburgh_Pirate.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Jim_Russell-_Pittsburgh_Pirate.jpg) Uniform design in the 1940s The Pirates have had many uniforms and logo changes over the years, with the only consistency being the "P" on the team's cap. Like other teams in Major League Baseball, the Pirates predominantly favored a patriotic red, white and blue color scheme through the first half of the 20th Century.[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Pirates#cite_note-sportslogos.net-43) During this time, the Pirates predominantly wore a blue cap, with either a red or white P. The uniforms were plain, often including a simple "P" if anything at all. The team's name was first acknowledged in 1912, with a pinstripe

bottom of the ticket inside the MLB Ballpark app you can tap the "Add to Wallet" button to add your ticket to Apple Wallet. #### Can I use Google Pay for my Pirates tickets? No. Support for adding tickets to Google Pay is not yet available from the MLB Ballpark app. #### Why won't my ticket barcode scan? If your screen brightness is too low, the barcode may have difficulty being scanned. The MLB Ballpark app will automatically attempt to increase the brightness of your display or you can do so manually by following the instructions for your device. Please note, cracked screens may impact your barcode's ability to scan. The barcode displayed is accompanied by a number. If there are difficulties reading a valid barcode on a digital ticket displayed within the MLB Ballpark app, visit the PNC Park Ticket Office. #### What if I lose connectivity after I've retrieved my tickets? As long as you have previously viewed your tickets, you will still be able to view your tickets in the MLB Ballpark app even with low connectivity. We recommend viewing and loading your tickets prior to arriving at PNC Park or adding to your Apple Wallet to ensure they are accessible regardless of connectivity. #### If I access my tickets from the MLB Ballpark app, can I still have them printed at a Will Call window? Since tickets retrieved within the MLB Ballpark app will now be considered printed, the tickets will not be available for pickup at Will Call. You should present the ticket displayed in the MLB Ballpark app on your mobile device for entry at the gate. If you are unable to access your ticket, go to a Ticket Office window for assistance on game day. If you have any questions, please contact Pirates Fans Services at [ticketservices@pirates.com](mailto:ticketservices@pirates.com) or 1-800-BUY-BUCS. #### What do I do if my mobile device's battery dies? Visit the nearest PNC Park Ticket Office window for assistance. [arrow-up-6\\ Back to Top](https://www.mlb.com/pirates/tickets/mobile/faqs#top) ### MLB BALLPARK APP - TICKET FORWARDING #### What is Ticket Forwarding? The MLB Ballpark app allows you to easily forward tickets to family, friends, colleagues, account partners and others with whom you wish to share your tickets so that they can use their ticket on their personal phone. #### How do I forward a ticket? From the Tickets tab’s Wallet tap on a game to access a list of your tickets. At the bottom of the list tap "Forward Ticket". Select the ticket(s) you wish to forward then choose "Select From Contacts", "Via Email", or “Share Link’. Selecting "Forward Ticket" again prompts you to enter an email address or choose a friend from your Address Book. You can then add the recipient's name (optional) and a message (optional) before tapping "Send" to complete the forward. If you wish to send by another method, you can tap "Share Link" which will provide you a unique link to share. You can also quickly send tickets to friends you’ve forwarded to recently by tapping on their email! #### Will the MLB Ballpark app

Dense.answer: The context provided does not specify who Pittsburgh is named after. It mentions the spelling history and some historical events related to Pittsburgh, but it does not provide information about the origin of the city's name.

contexts.text: said town of Pittsburgh shall be ... erected into a borough, which shall be called the borough of Pittsburgh for ever."[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh#cite_note-21) From 1891 to 1911, the city's name was federally recognized as "Pittsburg", though use of the final _h_ was retained during this period by the city government and other local organizations.[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh#cite_note-22)[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh#cite_note-spell-18) After a public campaign, the federal decision to drop the _h_ was reversed.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh#cite_note-spell-18) The _[Pittsburg Press](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Pittsburgh_Press "The Pittsburgh Press")_ continued spelling the city without an _h_ until 1921.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh#cite_note-23) ## History \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: History")\] Main article: [History of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pittsburgh "History of Pittsburgh") For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_Pittsburgh "Timeline of Pittsburgh"). Historical claims > ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Royal_Standard_of_the_King_of_France.svg/40px-Royal_Standard_of_the_King_of_France.svg.png)[Kingdom of France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_France "Kingdom of France") 1690s–1763 > > ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png)[Great Britain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") 1681–1781 > > ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Flag_of_the_United_States_%281848%E2%80%931851%29.svg/40px-Flag_of_the_United_States_%281848%E2%80%931851%29.svg.png)[United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States "United States") 1776–present ### Native Americans \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Native Americans")\] The area of the Ohio headwaters was long inhabited by the [Shawnee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shawnee "Shawnee") and several other settled groups of [Native Americans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas "Indigenous peoples of the Americas").[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh#cite_note-24) [Shannopin's Town](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shannopin%27s_Town "Shannopin's Town") was an 18th-century [Lenape](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lenape "Lenape") (Delaware) town located roughly from where [Penn Avenue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penn_Avenue "Penn Avenue") is today, below the mouth of Two Mile Run, from 30th Street to 39th Street. According to [George Croghan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Croghan "George Croghan"), the town was situated on the south bank of the Allegheny, nearly opposite what is now known as Washington's Landing, formerly [Herr's Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herrs_Island,_Pittsburgh "Herrs Island, Pittsburgh"), in what is now the [Lawrenceville](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawrenceville_(Pittsburgh) "Lawrenceville (Pittsburgh)") neighborhood.[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh#cite_note-Hanna1-25): 289 ### 18th century \[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pittsburgh&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: 18th century")\] Further information: [Pennsylvania in the American Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania_in_the_American_Revolution "Pennsylvania in the American Revolution") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Bouquet_blockhouse.JPG/250px-Bouquet_blockhouse.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bouquet_blockhouse.JPG) [Fort Pitt Block House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Pitt_Block_House "Fort Pitt Block House"), built by the British in 1764, is the oldest extant structure in Pittsburgh. The first known European to enter the region was the French explorer [Robert de La Salle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_de_La_Salle "Robert de La Salle") from [Quebec](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quebec "Quebec") during his 1669 expedition down the [Ohio River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_River "Ohio River").[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh#cite_note-26)\[ _[better source needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS "Wikipedia:NOTRS")_\] European pioneers, primarily Dutch, followed in the early 18th century. Michael Bezallion was the first to describe the forks of the Ohio in a 1717 manuscript, and later that year European [fur traders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fur_trade "Fur trade") established area posts and settlements.[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh#cite_note-chronology-27) In 1749, French soldiers from Quebec launched an expedition to the forks to unite [Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada_(New_France) "Canada (New France)") with [French Louisiana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louisiana_(New_France) "Louisiana (New France)") via the rivers.[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh#cite_note-chronology-27) During 1753–1754, the British hastily built [Fort Prince George](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Prince_George "Fort Prince George") before a larger French force drove them off. The French built [Fort Duquesne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Duquesne "Fort Duquesne") based on LaSalle's 1669 claims. The [French and Indian War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_and_Indian_War "French and Indian War"), the North American front of the [Seven Years' War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War "Seven Years' War"), began with the future Pittsburgh as its center. British General [Edward Braddock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Braddock "Edward Braddock") was dispatched with Major [George Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Washington "George Washington") as his aide to take Fort Duquesne.[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh#cite_note-WDL-28) The British and colonial force were defeated at [Braddock's Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Braddock%27s_Field "Braddock's Field"). General John Forbes finally took the forks in 1758. He began construction on [Fort Pitt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Pitt_(Pennsylvania) "Fort Pitt (Pennsylvania)"), named after [William Pitt the Elder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Pitt_the_Elder "William Pitt the Elder"), while the

\\ \\ Unexpected Arts \\ \\ Discover unique art venues in Pittsburgh, including The Andy Warhol Museum and Mattress Factory.\\ \\ Details](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/blog/unexpected-arts/) # Visual Arts No matter your artistic style, Pittsburgh has a museum for you. Be astonished by art crafted from flowers at [Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens](https://www.visitpittsburgh.com/directory/phipps-conservatory-and-botanical-gardens/), or explore the history of work created in southwest Pennsylvania and across the country at the newly expanded [Westmoreland Museum of American Art](http://thewestmoreland.org/). The classical art collection at [The Frick Pittsburgh](http://www.thefrickpittsburgh.org/) includes early Italian Renaissance painting and much more. One of the most dynamic major art institutions in America, [The Carnegie Museum of Art](https://cmoa.org/), is committed to global engagement by championing creativity and houses an archive of nearly 80,000 photographic negatives from Pittsburgh photographer [Teenie Harris](http://cmoa.org/art/teenie-harris-archive/). The [Andy Warhol Museum](https://www.warhol.org/) holds the largest collection of Warhol art in the world. Contemporary art museum [Mattress Factory](http://www.mattress.org/) features installations created by artists in residence.
